review & editing Funding acquisition a b * a Department of Petroleum Technology and Alternative Fuels, University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague, Czech Republic Department of Petroleum Technology and Alternative Fuels University of Chemistry and Technology Prague Technická 5 Prague 166 28 Czech Republic Department of Petroleum Technology and Alternative Fuels, University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague, Czech Republic b Technopark Kralupy, University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Žižkova 7, 278 01 Kralupy nad Vltavou, Czech Republic Technopark Kralupy University of Chemistry and Technology Prague Žižkova 7 Kralupy nad Vltavou 278 01 Czech Republic Technopark Kralupy, University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Žižkova 7, 278 01 Kralupy nad Vltavou, Czech Republic c Department of Physical Chemistry, Faculty of Chemical Technology, University of Pardubice, Studentská 573, 532 10 Pardubice, Czech Republic Department of Physical Chemistry Faculty of Chemical Technology University of Pardubice Studentská 573 Pardubice 532 10 Czech Republic Department of Physical Chemistry, Faculty of Chemical Technology, University of Pardubice, Studentská 573, 532 10 Pardubice, Czech Republic ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Petroleum Technology and Alternative Fuels, University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague, Czech Republic Department of Petroleum Technology and Alternative Fuels University of Chemistry and Technology Prague Technická 5 Prague 166 28 Czech Republic Graphical abstract The well-established ester hydrogenolysis process has to be further improved to reduce its high energy demand and to replace used Adkins CuCr catalysts by chromium-free alternatives. In this study, the copper-based catalyst was modified by ZnO, ZnO with Al2O3 or MgO to elucidate the metal-oxide influence on catalyst structure, activity, performance and stability in ester hydrogenolysis. The catalysts composition, structure and physicochemical properties were examined by AAS, XRD, TPR, BET, N2O-RFC, TGA-MS, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD. It was confirmed that copper itself possesses high intrinsic activity for ester hydrogenolysis but the unpromoted copper species were very unstable. All used metal oxides were proven to be structural promoters stabilizing copper species and increasing the number of active sites. Consequently, they enhanced remarkably catalyst performance in dimethyl adipate conversion despite the decreased intrinsic activity of Cu active sites. All prepared catalysts outperformed a commercial CuCr catalyst in dimethyl adipate hydrogenolysis. Keywords Copper catalyst ester hydrogenolysis dimethyl adipate promoter copper intrinsic activity 1 Introduction Ester hydrogenolysis is a well-established catalytic process producing alcohols of various chain length. Fatty alcohols production volume was estimated to be 3 million tons in 2022 [1]. The produced alcohols may be used in the cosmetic and pharmaceutical industry, manufacture of polyurethanes or polyesters [1]. The process uses well-known Adkins catalysts based on mainly CuO and Cr2O3 that were developed more than 80 years ago [2]. The process is energy-intensive operated at temperatures over 250 °C and hydrogen pressure over 25 MPa [3,4]. Thus, according to Green Chemistry principles established more than 20 years ago, there are two main weaknesses of this well-established process – use of harmful Cr-containing catalysts (the manufacture of the Cr-catalyst and the related toxic waste management has to be taken into account) and high energy demand [5]. The functional role of Cr2O3 is a structural promoter increasing the catalyst surface area and improving the copper particles thermal stability [3,6–8], while the essential hydrogenolytically active site of Adkins catalysts is metallic copper. However, single-phase Cu catalyst was shown to be unstable due to the easy sintering of copper particles resulting in a low active surface area [9]. Therefore, the strategy is to develop environmentally friendly hydrogenolysis catalysts using Cu° as the active site and replace Cr2O3 by a different structural promoter. To be classified as a promoter, metal oxide has to enhance catalyst performance, which can be achieved in several ways. First, metal oxides could be used as supports providing a large surface area and increasing the metal dispersion [10]. In co-precipitated catalysts, metal oxides can increase surface density of active sites (i.e. active metal surface area) and prevent their sintering or make reduction of active site easier due to the structural modifications or electronic effects [11,12]. In both cases, metal oxides can be called structural promoters. On the other hand, an activity promoter enhances intrinsic activity of active sites of the catalyst (evaluated as turnover frequency (TOF)). In addition, a promoter may also either suppress or enhance the formation of a particular product acting as a selectivity modifier or promoter [13]. Previously, Cr2O3 was replaced with another metal oxides such as ZnO, Al2O3, ZrO2 or MgO [9,14–16]. These metal oxides modified the catalyst structure, texture, acid-base properties and also the catalytic performance in hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions [9,14,17–19]. Cu catalysts promoted by ZnO and ZnO-Al2O3 were used in hydrogenolysis of e.g. dimethyl succinate [20], dimethyl maleate [21], glycerol [18,22] and dimethyl adipate (DMA) [9,15,23,24]. During the DMA hydrogenolysis over Cu-ZnO and Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 catalysts, a wide range of transesterification products was formed decreasing the selectivity to desired hexane-1,6-diol to as low as 30 % [23,24]. Previously, the experiments with a differently pre-treated Cu-ZnO catalyst precursor showed that Cu-ZnO catalysts have different active sites for hydrogenolysis and transesterification [23,25]. In addition, Yuan et al. detected cyclization by-products in DMA hydrogenolysis using a Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst [15]. Transesterification, as well as cyclization or dehydration reactions, are typically associated with acid-base catalyst properties [26–28]. These properties are influenced by the catalyst composition, e.g. by the nature of promoters in the Cu-based co-precipitated catalysts. The incorporation of ZnO or Al2O3 can introduce Lewis acid sites while the MgO enhances the Lewis basicity of the catalysts [14,29]. The effects are, however, not straightforward as they affect other parameters, namely BET surface area, specific copper surface area as well as the copper dispersion and reducibility, that then affect catalytic performance [30–32]. Cui et al. confirmed that neither acid nor basic sites, but the ratio of acid to basic sites and even more their ratio to the active metal is the most important [33]. In particular, the ratio Cu : Lewis acid sites : medium-strong basic sites was shown to be crucial for the selectivity in hydrogenolysis of dimethyl oxalate [33]. Basically, acid sites polarize C = O bond and basic sites facilitate hydrogenolysis of C-O bond due to the interaction with π* acceptor orbital of C = O bond [33–35]. The importance of basic sites was shown by MgO incorporation into Cu-Al2O3 catalyst for hydrogenolysis of ethyl levulinate, where the increased basicity promoted hydrogenolysis rather than cyclization reactions facilitated by Lewis acid sites [36]. It is thus obvious that by choosing an appropriate promoter the formation of side products may be suppressed and the efficacy of the hydrogenolysis process increased side products while preserving the rather mild reaction conditions. To provide a complex insight in the role of metal oxides on the catalysts performance and activity of Cu catalysts in hydrogenolysis, we have focused on a systematic investigation of a series of potential structural promoters, including ZnO, Al2O3 and MgO to vary primarily the acid-base catalyst properties. As previously the Cu/Zn ratio equal to 1 was reported to be optimal both in glycerol and DMA hydrogenolysis [9,18], we have kept the copper-to-metal ratio equal to 1. In addition, we have investigated an unpromoted single-phase Cu catalyst as a reference point to assess the effect of promoters on the physicochemical properties of the resulting catalysts. Moreover, we have studied a commercial Adkins Cu-Cr2O3 catalyst as a benchmark of the catalytic performance. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Catalyst preparation To investigate the effect of variation in the composition of Cu-based hydrogenolysis catalysts on their properties and performance, ZnO, Al2O3 and MgO were used to modify a neat Cu catalyst. The Cu catalyst precursor, denoted as Cu_P, was prepared by precipitation of aqueous solution of Cu(NO3)2.3H2O by solution of Na2CO3 at 60 °C and pH of 7. Similarly, the CuZn catalyst precursor, CuZn_P, was prepared by co-precipitation of aqueous solutions of Cu(NO3)2.3H2O and Zn(NO3)2.6H2O in molar ratio 1:1 by solution of Na2CO3 at 60 °C and pH of 7. More detailed description of the used co-precipitation procedure was previously reported [9]. The CuMg catalyst precursor CuMg_P, was prepared by co-precipitation of aqueous solutions of Cu(NO3)2.3H2O and Mg(NO3)2.6H2O in molar ratio 1:1 by solution of Na2CO3 at 60 °C and pH of 9. The CuZnAl catalyst precursors CuZnAl_P were prepared by co-precipitating of aqueous solutions of Cu(NO3)2.3H2O, Zn(NO3)2.6H2O and Al(NO3)3.9H2O with molar ratio of Cu/(Zn + Al) equal to 1 by solution of Na2CO3 at 60 °C and pH of 7. All suspensions of precipitates were then aged, filtered, washed and dried. More specific details are provided in Table SI1. All precursors, i.e. the as-prepared materials were denoted with the ending “_P”. Prior to the use in catalytic experiments, all catalyst precursors were calcined ex situ in an oven in air atmosphere at 350 °C with a heating ramp of 2 °C min-1 and holding constant temperature for 3 hours. The calcined catalysts were denoted with the ending “_C”, i.e. CuZn_C denotes the catalyst obtained by calcination of the CuZn_P. In addition, a commercial CuCr catalyst was used as a benchmark. To characterize reduced catalysts, the calcined samples were reduced in 10% H2/Ar (90 ml·min-1) where the temperature gradually increased from the room temperature to 220 °C (1 °C min-1) and the final temperature was kept for 2 h. The samples were then cooled down to 28 °C in nitrogen flow for 20 min. At the final stage, the reduced samples were passivated by 1% O2/Ar flow for 2 h. The reduced samples were denoted with the ending “_R”. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The elemental composition of the catalyst precursors was determined by XRF using a spectrometer ARL 9400 XP equipped with a rhodium lamp or by AAS using Agilent 280FS AA, where mixtures of acetylene and air or acetylene and N2O were used as an atomization flame. Diffractometer PANanalytical X’Pert3 Powder and Cu Kα radiation were used to determine the phase composition of the catalyst precursors, calcined, reduced and spent catalysts. The XRD patterns were recorded in a range of 2θ = 5°– 70°. In addition, the crystallite sizes of Cu and Zn and Mg species in calcined and spent catalysts were calculated using the Scherrer’s equation. Reflections at 2θ = 31.8°, 38.6°, 43.0° and 43.3° were used for the crystallite size calculations for ZnO, CuO, MgO and Cu, respectively [37]. Equilibrium adsorption isotherms of nitrogen were measured at 77 K for calcined, reduced and spent catalysts using a static volumetric adsorption system (TriFlex analyzer, Micromeritics, Norcross, USA). The samples were degassed at 473 K (12 hours) prior to N2 adsorption analysis, in order to obtain a clean surface. The adsorption isotherms were fitted using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method for the specific surface area [38] and the BJH method for the distribution of mesopores [39]. TPR-measurements to assess the degree of Cu reduction were performed using Quantachrome ChemStar TPx instrument with a TCD detector. The samples were exposed to a reducing gas mixture containing 10 vol.% of hydrogen in argon with a flow of 50 ml·min-1. A U-shaped reactor with a calcined catalyst sample (typically 0.15 g) was located in a furnace and treated with the reducing gas at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1 from room temperature up to 600 °C. The hydrogen consumption was calculated using a calibration curve. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD was measured using AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics) equipped with a TCD and an MS (Omnistar GSD320) detector. First, the calcined catalyst samples were heated to 350 °C in a helium atmosphere and after cooling down (to 70 °C for NH3 and 25 °C for CO2) 5% NH3 in He (15 ml·min-1) or 10% CO2 in He were introduced and NH3 or CO2, respectively, were adsorbed for 30 min. Then physisorbed NH3 or CO2, were removed using helium flow (25 ml·min-1, 70 °C for NH3 and 25 °C for CO2, 1 h) and desorption of NH3 or CO2 was started by heating the catalyst sample at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 at a constant He flow (25 ml·min-1). The amount of desorbed NH3 or CO2 was monitored by an MS detector. The passivated samples were re-reduced in-situ in flow of 5% H2/Ar at 220 °C for 20 min prior to the adsorption of NH3 or CO2, respectively. The results are presented as relative mass 16/4 (NH3) and 44/4 (CO2), where the m/z signals 16 and 44 were divided by the signal of He used as carrier gas to reach higher precision. The copper specific surface area was determined using Autochem II 2920 (Micromiretics, USA) connected on-line to a quadrupole mass spectrometer RGA 200 (Prevac) by a reactive frontal chromatography method using N2O. The detailed procedure was described previously [9]. 2.3 Experimental setup The calcined catalyst powders were pressed and crushed to obtain the catalyst particle size of 0.10-0.25 mm. The catalysts amount of 4 g (CuCr, CuZnAl and CuMg) or 5 g (Cu, CuZn) was loaded into a fixed-bed reactor between two SiC layers (0.25-0.30 mm) allowing positioning of the catalyst bed in the reactor and pre-heating and mixing of the feedstock with hydrogen. The reactor equipped with a thermowell with thermocouples in its axis was placed in an electrically-heated oven. The catalysts were reduced in situ at 220 °C in N2/H2 atmosphere to avoid catalyst overheating during its reduction. The detailed procedure was described previously [9]. Dimethyl adipate (DMA, >99%, Merck) and hydrogen (>99.999, SIAD) were used as feedstocks in the experiments. To evaluate the hydrogenolysis performance of the catalysts, reaction temperature varied in the range of 160-205 °C, while other parameters were kept constant, namely hydrogen pressure at 160 bar (100 bar in case of CuMg_C), WHSV at 4 gDMA· h-1 ·gcat -1 and molar ratio of H2/DMA at 8 for all tested catalysts. The liquid products were collected each 120 min at a steady state at each reaction condition and analysed by GC-FID (ULTRA-1, i.d. 0.32 mm, length 15 m, program: 40 °C held for 2 min, heating ramp of 8 °C min-1, 280 °C held for 15 min, inlet temperature at 320 °C, detector temperature at 320 °C). The samples were diluted in butanol for this purpose. We have experimentally confirmed that the tests were not conducted under diffusional limitations. Details are provided in SI. 2.4 Calculations The conversion of dimethyl adipate (DMA) was evaluated using equation 1. The selectivity to individual products originating from DMA was calculated according to equation 2 on the basis of the C6 carbon-carbon (C-C) chain of DMA. This approach is justified by the absence of cracking reactions and, thus, full preservation of the C6 C-C chain units in the products. Based on a series of catalytic tests at the same reaction conditions over CuZnAl catalyst, we determined the experimental error being less than 6 %. The results in Table 1 clearly show that the preparation of all promoted catalyst precursors was successful as the ratio of Cu to the sum of all promoting elements was close to 1 (Table 1). To choose calcination temperature, the TGA-MS of catalyst precursors was recorded. The patterns (Fig. 1 ) suggested that as-prepared materials are being decomposed up to 500 °C and MS data collected during the TGA confirmed that H2O and CO2 were the two main products released during the thermal treatment of the precursors (Fig. 1). Up to 250 °C the physically adsorbed and interlayer H2O were removed while H2O observed at temperatures over 250 °C was assigned to dehydroxylation [40]. But, we previously reported that CuZn precursor calcined at 350 °C for 3 h had the better activity and catalytic properties than when calcined at 500 °C [9]. The precursors were calcined in the same way and TGA-MS of calcined CuZnAl precursor showed 5 % mass loss between 350-700 °C (Figure SI1) that is related to the presence of “high-temperature carbonates” [4,41]. In contrast, in case of the CuZn catalyst equally calcined, the mass loss up to 700 °C was negligible (0.5 %) confirming the complete decomposition of CuZn precursors after calcination at 350 °C for 3 h. The presence of crystalline phases in calcined precursors was determined using XRD (Fig. 2 B). In contrast to the TGA records of as-prepared catalyst precursors (Fig. 1), the XRD patterns of calcined precursors indicated that the hydroxycarbonates, as identified in as-prepared samples (Fig. 2A and described in detail in SI), should be indeed completely decomposed and no residual crystalline hydroxycarbonate phases were detected. In particular, malachite (MAL) and CuZn-hydroxycarbonates (aurichalcite (AU) and zincian malachite (ZM)) as the crystalline phase in catalysts precursors Cu_P and CuZn_P were fully decomposed to CuO (2θ = 38.6°) or CuO and ZnO (2θ = 31.7°), respectively, as also reported previously [9,16]. Similarly, the CuZnAl as-prepared catalyst precursor containing well-crystalline hydrotalcite-like structure (HTC) and ZM was decomposed to crystalline CuO, but no ZnO-related diffraction lines were detected. Taking into account the amorphous Al2O3 phase that is invisible by means of XRD, an amorphous structure containing both ZnO and Al2O3 could be also formed [42]. In addition, in case of calcined CuZnAl and CuMg precursors, there are high-temperature carbonates still present and completely decomposed at temperature over 450 °C (Fig. 1). Nonetheless, they are not visible in the XRD diffractograms because they are either amorphous or their concentration or crystallite size is below the XRD detection limits. The benefit of the full decomposition was not proved yet as the calcination at 550 °C or higher temperature would result at the same time in significant growth in the CuO and ZnO crystallite sizes [9]. Moreover, the crystallite size of CuO (2θ = 38.6°), which is a precursor of the Cu crystallites active in hydrogenolysis reactions, was estimated by XRD using the Scherrer’s equation (Table 2 ). Predictably, the crystallite size of CuO in the unpromoted Cu_C was the largest among all calcined precursors (11 nm). The presence of metal oxides was beneficial for the stability of CuO crystallites and the CuO crystallite size in CuZn_C and CuZnAl_C was in the range of 4-5 nm. The crystallinity of CuMg_C was not sufficient to determine reliably crystalline phases present and their crystallite sizes. The CuO crystallite size in the CuCr catalyst was 9 nm. The different crystallite size of CuO in the Cu-based calcined precursors originates from the inherently different CuO crystallite growth during the calcination depending on the amount and nature of structural promoters. Consequently, the specific surface area of the calcined precursors was also influenced by the metal oxide. The Cu_C catalyst (obtained by malachite calcination) exhibited a BET surface area of only 15 m2 g-1, while the BET area of modified calcined precursors reached values in the range of 37-91 m2 g-1 (Table 2). The largest BET area was obtained for the CuMg_C catalyst. This is in agreement with the increase in the specific surface area after the addition of Mg to CuZn or CuZnAl catalytic systems [41]. On the other hand, the CuZnAl calcined precursor had a relatively low BET surface area of 37 m2 g-1. Considering the decreased copper crystallite size and increased BET area in the modified catalysts, the used metal oxides will be denoted as structural promoters. As the active site in hydrogenolysis reactions is Cu°, the reducibility of the calcined precursors was assessed, and differences were observed in the reduction profiles of individual samples (Fig. 3 ). Mostly, the reduction of Cu species was accomplished below 220 °C (Fig. 3). This includes reduction of all types of Cu species (CuII → CuI → Cu° and surface or bulk CuO). The profiles do not, however, allow discriminating between different Cu species. Only the reduction profile of calcined CuZnAl sample exhibited a right-hand-side shoulder at ca. 230 °C and measurable hydrogen consumption at temperatures in the range of 300–600 °C (Fig. 3). Based on the Cu content, it was ascertained that the experimentally measured hydrogen consumption (up to 300 °C) corresponded to theoretical calculated value. The reduced and passivated samples were then analysed using XRD to estimate Cu crystallite size (Table 2 and Fig. 4 ). The stabilization of Cu species was confirmed in CuZnAl_R sample since the Cu crystallite size was still around 5 nm while in CuZn_R samples increased from 5 nm to 8 nm. The CuCr_R sample was stable about 8 nm. On the other hand, the Cu crystallite size in CuO-derived catalyst was 10-times larger than in CuZnAl that proved that the addition of metal oxides helped to stabilize Cu species during the thermal treatment and could be called structural promoter. The used promoters allowed increasing the copper surface area of the catalysts and thus significantly enhancing the number of active sites that should have a positive effect on the catalyst performance. 3.2 Evaluation of acid-base properties In our previous study, we have shown that transesterification products were significant by-products or even reaction intermediates during the hydrogenolysis of dimethyl adipate [9,23–25]. It is well known that transesterification is an acid-base catalysed reaction [43]. Thus, the acid-base properties of the here employed materials were determined by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD for calcined precursors (described in detail in SI, Figure SI2) and reduced catalysts (Fig. 5 ). The material acidity was evaluated based on relative mass 16/4 during NH3-TPD that corresponds mainly to the signal of NH3. However, H2O and CO2 released from the materials during heating may also partially contribute to the 16/4 signal. This contribution was not observed in calcined samples due to the sample pre-treatment at 350 °C. However, the catalyst reduction at 220 °C (also pre-treated at 220 °C) resulted in changes in the catalysts structure and, thus, H2O and CO2 signals were observed at as low temperature as 250 °C. This change made the determination of acid sites more complicated as it was required to subtract the signal corresponding to the H2O and CO2 release. Taking into account the measured signals 15/4, 16/4, 17/4, 18/4, 32/4 and 44/4, relative mass signal intensities of CO2, NH3, H2O, and O2 [44] and assuming the overall signal is a linear combination of the signals from H2O, CO2 and NH3, the original TPD patterns were evaluated by chemometrics and the patterns were divided into individual components – CO2, NH3, H2O and O2. Thus, CO2 and H2O released from the catalyst structure could be eliminated and the real signal of desorbed NH3 and CO2 could be plotted. The original TPD patterns are shown in Figure SI4 and the TPD patterns without interferences in Fig. 5. The results confirmed the conclusions obtained for the calcined samples, i.e. that there are weak acid sites present from which NH3 was desorbed in the temperature range of 100-250 °C, accompanied by some moderate acid sites at 280 °C in CuCr_R, CuZnAl_R, and CuMg_R and strong acid sites >300 °C in CuCr_R (Fig. 5). The original signal of 16/4 from NH3-TPD observed in reduced samples at >300 °C was corrected and it was shown to originate from H2O and CO2 release. Especially in CuMg_R sample, where all signal that would correspond to strong acid sites was in fact due to H2O and CO2 (contributing to the 16/4 signal) desorption. This could be caused by either changing the catalyst structure during reduction and modifying, thus, the decomposition temperature of the original high-temperature carbonates (i.e. those that did not decompose at temperatures below the calcination temperature of 350 °C) or adsorption of CO2 and H2O during catalyst storage and manipulation. This was proven by a blank experiment where the sample was thermally treated in an inert atmosphere using the same heating program as in the NH3-TPD (Figure SI4). The total number of acid sites up to 500 °C after proper evaluation of the measured signals increased in the reduced catalysts in the order Cu_R < CuMg_R ≈ CuZn_R < CuZnAl_R < CuCr_R (Fig. 5 and Table 2). The tendency is unchanged compared to calcined samples as the promoters in oxidic state are mainly responsible for the catalyst acidity (Figure SI2). This was confirmed in the reduced sample Cu_R, where acidity reached only about 5 μmol·g-1. Hence, the observed acidity in the promoted samples can be attributed to the promoters. On the other hand, the CuCr_R sample had the highest number of acid sites, where the surface acidity corresponds with presence of Cr2O3. The catalyst acidity was shown to increase with the increasing concentration of Cr2O3 [45]. Among the prepared catalysts, the most acidic character was observed in CuZnAl_R due to the acidic character of the alumina phase that was formed during calcination. As the bulk concentration of Cr2O3 was about 1.7-times higher than that of Al2O3 in the promoted catalysts, it could contribute the higher observed acidity of the CuCr_R catalyst in comparison with the CuZnAl_R catalyst. Interestingly, the incorporation of ZnO also resulted in an increased acidity of the CuZn_R catalyst compared to Cu catalyst. The highest concentration of acid sites was reached in Cu_R (2.5 μmol·m-2) due to its very low BET surface area, followed by CuCr_R (1.6 μmol·m-2), CuZnAl_R (1.5 μmol·m-2) and CuZn_R (0.7 μmol·m-2) (Table 2). A different strength of acid sites was also observed. Besides weak acid sites in the range of 100-250 °C, also stronger sites were present. It is clearly visible that CuCr_R had the highest amount of moderate and strong acid sites at temperature over 250 °C related to the presence of Cr2O3 [46,47]. The amount of moderate acid sites at 280 °C decreased in the order CuCr_C > CuZnAl_R > CuMg_R > CuZn_R. As proven by the analysis of NH3-TPD data, there was CO2 desorbed from the reduced catalyst samples. Consequently, it was necessary to subtract the total amount of desorbed CO2 originating from the catalyst (determined in the NH3-TPD experiments) from the total amount of desorbed CO2 determined from the CO2-TPD experiments to obtain the real amount of CO2 adsorbed on the basic sites of the catalysts during the CO2-TPD experiment. The final pattern is present in Fig. 5. Based on the TPD-NH3 data, CO2 was detected only at temperatures over 250 °C and therefore the 44/4 signal below that value is related exclusively to CO2 adsorbed during the CO2-TPD measurements. The same finding was proven by chemometrics and weak basic sites with a maximum at 90 °C were observed in reduced catalysts (Fig. 5) as well as in the calcined samples (Figure SI3). The remaining basic sites >250 °C could not be properly described, because their origin cannot be at this moment unequivocally assigned. The largest amount of weak basic sites was determined in CuMg_R (50 μmol·g-1) and CuCr_R (49 μmol·g-1), while the CuZn_R and CuZnAl_R had a lower amount of 32 and 27 μmol·g-1, respectively. Then, the total amount of basic sites decreased in the order CuMg_R ≈ CuCr_R > CuZnAl_R ≈ CuZn_R > Cu_R. Similarly to catalyst acidity, due to the very low BET surface area, Cu_R had the highest density of basic sites (3.6 μmol·m-2). The basic sites density in the rest of the catalysts was in the range of 0.6-1.0 μmol·m-2. These CO2 desorption peaks were previously attributed to the presence of surface hydroxyl groups [48,49]. They are generally denoted as weak basic sites in the literature on mixed oxides catalysts. The remaining basic sites were not described. 3.3 Catalysts performance All catalysts were tested in dimethyl adipate hydrogenolysis with the aim to produce hexane-1,6-diol (HDOL). The modification of a Cu catalyst by ZnO, ZnO-Al2O3, MgO or Cr2O3 was studied to describe their influence on the catalyst performance. Malachite-derived catalyst consisting of single-phase CuO was not stable under reduction to the active metallic Cu phase as its BET area dropped from 15 to 1.9 m2 g-1 and Cu crystallite size dramatically increased due to liability to sintering from 11.3 to 43 nm. As a result, only 30 % DMA conversion at 205 °C was reached [9]. A significantly improved catalyst performance was observed when about a half of CuO was replaced by the metal oxide, i.e. ZnO, ZnO-Al2O3, Cr2O3 or MgO. The CuZn catalyst provided the highest DMA conversion of 97 % at 205 °C. When the combination of ZnO and Al2O3 was used, the maximum DMA conversion decreased to 81 % (Fig. 6 ). The promotion of Cu by MgO (CuMg) was not such sufficient and resulted in DMA conversion of 61 %, the lowest among the prepared modified catalysts. Surprisingly, the benchmark CuCr catalyst was not efficient at the tested reaction conditions reaching conversion only about 30 %, i.e. its performance was comparable to that of Cu catalyst (Fig. 6). This unexpected behaviour could be explained by the mild reaction conditions as significantly more severe reaction conditions with hydrogen pressure >250 bar and temperature >250 °C are used in the industrial setup using CuCr hydrogenolysis catalysts in liquid phase processes [15]. Hence, it can be concluded that metal oxides, particularly the ZnO, ZnO with Al2O3 and MgO enhanced catalyst performance and acted as catalyst promoters. Also, they were more efficient than the commercial benchmark catalyst under less energy-demanding reaction conditions. As Cu0 is the active site in hydrogenolysis of esters, it could be expected that the DMA conversion would increase with the increasing specific copper surface area of different catalysts. The catalytic results follow this dependency only partially (Figure SI5 and Fig. 6), which can be attributed to the influence of Cu surroundings on the active Cu site, promoter properties and interaction with DMA as well as reaction intermediates. The most striking deviation from the expected trend was seen for CuMg that afforded lower DMA conversion than CuZn and CuZnAl catalysts despite it had similar or significantly higher Cu specific area (Table 2). It can be proposed that this is a consequence of a negative effect of MgO on the intrinsic activity of the Cu crystallites. Another peculiar observation that is out of the expected trend is the very low DMA conversion over the commercial CuCr catalyst that is even lower than the DMA conversion over Cu having more than twice lower Cu surface area (2 vs. 5 m2 g-1). Based just on the DMA conversion under mild reaction conditions, the catalysts could be divided into 2 groups - potentially perspective catalysts (CuZn, CuZnAl and CuMg) and catalysts providing too low DMA conversion (Cu and CuCr). However, to evaluate the intrinsic Cu activity in the studied catalysts, turnover frequency (TOF) has to be used to normalize the observed performance per the number of surface copper atoms, i.e. the number of active sites. The TOF values were evaluated at 175 °C where generally lower conversion levels were reached for all tested catalysts (Fig. 6). Based on the calculated TOF, two groups of catalysts can be distinguished – with a lower TOF, which includes CuCr and CuMg catalysts, and with a higher TOF, which consists of CuZn, CuZnAl and the unpromoted Cu catalyst (Fig. 7 ). The high TOF of the Cu catalyst results from its very low number of active sites and suggests a high intrinsic activity of the surface Cu atoms supported on bulk Cu. On the other hand, the Cu catalyst showed larger particles and their lower stability and low specific surface, due to the absence of a structural promoter, make it inefficient in terms of its overall performance. Nonetheless, from the catalyst design point of view, it is noteworthy that the best-promoted catalysts, i.e. those containing ZnO, exhibited the same or slightly lower TOF values. It can be inferred that a weaker kind of electronic interactions between the active Cu species and promoter is preferable. It also confirms that the role of the promoter is a purely structural one, i.e. it acts as a spacer between the active Cu clusters. Consequently, ZnO appears as the most efficient catalyst structural promoter. On the other hand, Cr2O3 and MgO modified catalyst exhibit plausibly a stronger interaction between Cu and the metal oxide. The presence of BaO in the Adkins catalyst may have a similar effect on the intrinsic Cu activity as MgO. Moreover, the interaction of Cu clusters with ZnO-Al2O3, Cr2O3, and/or ZnO might also negatively influence the Cu intrinsic activity. So, ZnO and ZnO with Al2O3 are catalyst structural promoters rather than activity promoters. Although the intrinsic Cu activity dropped due to these structural promoters, the number of catalyst active sites significantly increased and thus, the overall performance was enhanced. With the exception of CuMg, the Cu intrinsic activity correlated with the number of catalyst acid-base sites as with the decreasing amount of these sites TOF value increased (Fig. 8 ). Thus, the materials with the lower number of acid-base sites seem to be preferable. The reason for the observed deviation of CuMg catalyst from the trend could be due to underestimation of the number of base sites. As discussed above, the evaluation of the amount of base sites was possible only to the desorption temperature of about 250 °C. Unlike in the other catalysts, CuMg catalyst could possess also moderate and strong base sites as indicated by the CO2-TPD analysis of calcined catalysts (Figure SI3). This is also supported by studies comparing the acid-base properties of ZnO, Al2O3 and MgO [50]. The main product of DMA hydrogenolysis is hexane-1,6-diol (HDOL), but other products can be formed as well (simplified scheme is depicted in Fig. 9 ). Several differences in the formation of HDOL and transesterification by-products were observed among the studied catalysts. The obvious reaction intermediate product is methyl 6-hydroxyhexanoate (1HMEol) that is formed by hydrogenolysis of only one of the two ester functional groups to a hydroxyl functional group (Fig. 9). Other detected products were formed via transesterification reactions between an ester functional group (present in DMA and 1HMEol) and a hydroxyl functional group (present in 1HMEol and HDOL). Commonly, two or three molecules were merged together forming molecules with C12 or C18 C-C chain. Heavier compounds with more than 3 hexane fragments were not detected by GC-FID but their formation in low concentrations cannot be excluded. The complete reaction scheme is presented in Figure SI6. Thus, there are 2 competitive reaction routes – transesterification and hydrogenolysis. To allow a concise evaluation of the experimental data, all products were grouped based on their structure into 3 groups according to their terminal functional groups – two alcohols (diol), two methyl ester groups (diME) and one of each group (MEol). The prefix “2H” indicates the number of hexane fragments. As we have shown previously, different active sites are responsible for hydrogenolysis and for transesterification reactions in CuZn catalysts [23]. In general, the selectivity to the main product, HDOL, increased with the increasing DMA conversion (Fig. 10 A). Thus, the highest selectivity to HDOL of 72 % was reached over CuZn followed by the other catalysts that exhibited a similar selectivity to HDOL in the range of 26 to 34 % at 205 °C, i.e. at the highest conversion reached. Nonetheless, the comparison of HDOL selectivity at the same DMA conversion revealed some differences (Fig. 10A). Although the CuCr catalyst reached the lowest DMA conversion (30 %), the HDOL selectivity was the highest at these low conversion among all tested catalysts (Fig. 10A) while the rest of the catalysts had similar dependence of HDOL selectivity on DMA conversion. The high selectivity to HDOL even at low conversion could be caused by fast conversion of reaction intermediate 1HMEol to HDOL facilitated by the moderate acid sites that enhanced its adsorption and pre-activation prior to hydrogenolysis on Cu active sites. At the DMA conversion of ca. 30 %, the CuZnAl and CuMg catalysts had lower selectivity to HDOL of around 20 % compared to the other catalysts. In case of DMA conversion over 50 %, the differences were even more pronounced. The most selective catalyst was CuZn, while CuZnAl and CuMg followed the same lower trend of HDOL selectivity dependence on DMA conversion (Fig. 10A). The differences in HDOL selectivity can be linked to the variation in the selectivity to the transesterification products formed by a reaction route competitive to hydrogenolysis. This variation is related to the differences in acid-base properties among the tested catalysts as the transesterification reactions are acid-base catalysed (Figure SI6). At the very beginning, 1HMEol as a primary hydrogenolysis reaction intermediate is created (Fig. 10B). Unpromoted Cu catalyst with the lowest surface area and the minimum of acid-base sites converted the reaction intermediate mainly to HDOL. Similarly, the second lowest amount of acid-base sites in CuZn along with the high copper specific surface area (14 m2 g-1) resulted in high catalytic activity and thus higher selectivity to HDOL, but with the same trend of HDOL selectivity vs. DMA conversion (Fig. 10A). Although CuCr showed higher HDOL formation at low conversions, the by-products formation was the same as in CuZn and Cu indicating that 1HMEol was converted to HDOL faster than over Cu and CuZn catalysts. This could be caused by CuCr moderate acid sites as suggested above. Thus, it is evident that the acid-base properties play a key role not only in Cu intrinsic activity, but also in the by-product formation. In case of CuCr, CuZnAl and CuMg that have more pronounced acid-base character, the reaction intermediate 1HMEol was converted to HDOL or to transesterification by-products more rapidly than over Cu and CuZn. The significant amount of moderate and strong acid-base sites in CuCr might increase the rate of second hydrogenolysis step, 1HMEol to HDOL, or even more, both ester groups in DMA may be hydrogenolyzed in one step (i.e. without desorption of the intermediate 1HMEol). These sites are not present in CuZnAl and CuMg and, thus, it can be suggested that they favour the conversion of 1HMEol to HDOL rather than to the transesterification by-products. Focusing on the transesterification products, namely individual 2H compounds (2HdiME, 2Hdiol and 2HMEol), their formation can be easily explained. First, 2HdiME is formed because it originates from the reaction of DMA and of the first reaction intermediate (1HMEol). Second, 2HMEol is formed from DMA and HDOL at higher conversions than 2HdiME as these are needed to reach a sufficient concentration of HDOL in the reaction mixture. The selectivity to these two compounds seems to be dependent on the catalyst type and also on the DMA conversion (Figure SI7). Their production was augmented when using CuZnAl and CuMg catalysts (Fig. 10C). The third product, 2Hdiol is formed from 1HMEol and HDOL and it seems to be dependent only on DMA conversion and thus on HDOL concentration. 1HMEol concentration among the tested catalysts did not affect 2Hdiol concentration (Figure SI7). Also, CuZnAl and CuMg catalysts produced large amounts (up to 10 %; Fig. 10D) of by-products consisting of three hexane fragments (3 H), i.e. the formation of the by-products can be unequivocally related to the acid-base properties of the catalysts. However, not only the total concentration of these sites is important; their strength plays an important role as well. It was reported previously that Cu catalyst was not stable, while the use of promoter such as ZnO or Cr2O3 helped to stabilize Cu clusters [9]. Here, CuZnAl catalyst did not show any deactivation; on the contrary, the conversion of DMA surprisingly increased with time-on-stream as well as over CuMg_C (Table 3 ). Preliminary, it can be suggested that it is a consequence of structural changes in the catalysts during the course of the reaction because BET surface area of CuZnAl catalyst was higher after the experiment while it decreased for the rest of spent catalysts except of CuCr (Table 2). These structural changes are still under investigation. The reaction was performed over metallic copper (2θ = 43.6°, 50.5°) that has been the only copper-containing phase identified by XRD in the spent catalysts (Fig. 11 ). The remaining reflections in XRD patterns of spent catalysts belong to SiC that was used as an inert matrix in the reactor. It is clear that catalytic performance, activity and selectivity depend on many aspects playing particular role such as acid-base sites (their total number, concentration and strength) activating the reactants, specific copper surface area (the place where hydrogenolysis occurs), accessibility of both Cu and acid-base sites for reactant and intermediates (that cannot be thoroughly described) and/or surface composition. Each of these aspects partially contributes to the final catalyst performance making the evaluation very complex. Moreover, the hydrogenolysis and transesterification are competitive reactions affecting each other as transesterification products may be converted on hydrogenolysis active sites back to hydrogenolysis products. Also, changes in catalyst structure may occur during the experiment, for example, the BET surface area of CuMg catalysts decreased more than four times while in CuZnAl it increased more than twice during the experiment that finally may affect the concentration of acid-base sites that is sensitive to BET surface area. Despite these uncertainties it is possible to draw several clear conclusions on the role of promoters on the hydrogenolysis activity of copper species. 4 Conclusions In this comprehensive study, catalyst properties, performance, activity and stability of co-precipitated Cu, CuZn, CuZnAl, CuMg catalysts were described and compared with a commercial CuCr catalyst. The incorporation of metal oxides improved catalysts properties, namely, increased BET surface area and specific copper area indicating that they work as structural promoters. The high impact of promoters was reflected in the complexity of catalysts reducibility and their complex acid-base properties. The stability of copper crystallites was successfully improved by the structural promoters. The copper intrinsic activity of the tested catalysts evaluated by TOF indicated that the promoters did not act as activity promoters. The reduced TOF of the promoted catalysts combined with their better catalytic performance clearly demonstrated that the role of the promoters was purely structural. Moreover, the intrinsic Cu hydrogenolysis activity was found to increase with the decreasing total number of acid-base sites in the studied catalysts. The use of metal oxides acting as structural promoters significantly improved their catalytic performance in dimethyl adipate hydrogenolysis. All promoted catalysts outperformed a commercial CuCr catalyst and the unpromoted Cu-catalyst at the tested reaction conditions. The highest dimethyl adipate conversion and selectivity to the main product, hexane-1,6-diol, were reached over CuZn catalyst that revealed ZnO as the most promising Cu promoter. coredata.dc:description: The well-established ester hydrogenolysis process has to be further improved to reduce its high energy demand and to replace used Adkins CuCr catalysts by chromium-free alternatives. In this study, the copper-based catalyst was modified by ZnO, ZnO with Al2O3 or MgO to elucidate the metal-oxide influence on catalyst structure, activity, performance and stability in ester hydrogenolysis. The catalysts composition, structure and physicochemical properties were examined by AAS, XRD, TPR, BET, N2O-RFC, TGA-MS, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD. It was confirmed that copper itself possesses high intrinsic activity for ester hydrogenolysis but the unpromoted copper species were very unstable. All used metal oxides were proven to be structural promoters stabilizing copper species and increasing the number of active sites. Consequently, they enhanced remarkably catalyst performance in dimethyl adipate conversion despite the decreased intrinsic activity of Cu active sites. All prepared catalysts outperformed a commercial CuCr catalyst in dimethyl adipate hydrogenolysis.
coredata.dc:title: Do metal-oxide promoters of Cu hydrogenolysis catalysts affect the Cu intrinsic activity?
